Topic: Draw two habitats and the different living things in each
CAN: The student can draw simple shapes or scribbles that might represent two different places (e.g., a rectangle for land and a wavy shape for water) but without clear distinction as habitats.
The student can add objects that resemble animals or plants in one or both areas, but without variety or clear distinction (e.g., triangles for trees or random circles for fish).
CANNOT: The student cannot accurately portray two distinct habitats (e.g., both areas look similar or indistinguishable).
The student cannot include a variety of plants and animals or mix up what belongs in each habitat (e.g., putting fish in the land habitat or showing the same animal in both areas).
The student may not understand or demonstrate the diversity of habitats (e.g., draws the same type of plant or animal in both habitats with no variation).
The student cannot use their drawing to compare the variety of living things between habitats (no observed pattern or comparison shown).
